title: UK immigration policy: What changes are being made? - BBC News

segments.text: The government has announced sweeping changes to immigration policy
aimed at reducing net migration figures which have reached record levels
The Home Secretary outlined plans to tighten visa requirements
particularly for workers coming from outside the European Union
Critics say the measures could damage the economy
with sectors like healthcare and agriculture relying heavily on migrant workers
The NHS has warned that restricting immigration could worsen staff shortages
Hospitals across England are already struggling with record waiting times
Business leaders have expressed concern about the impact on growth
The CBI called for a more balanced approach to migration policy
Meanwhile asylum seekers continue to cross the English Channel in small boats
with numbers reaching unprecedented levels this year
The Rwanda deportation scheme remains controversial
with legal challenges still pending in the courts
Opposition parties have criticized the government for failing to control borders
Labour says it would take a different approach focusing on enforcement
The public remains deeply divided on the issue of immigration
Polls suggest a majority want reduced numbers but recognize economic benefits
Communities in areas with high immigration report mixed feelings
Some welcome the cultural diversity while others express concerns
about pressure on public services and housing
The debate around immigration shows no signs of cooling down
as the government prepares for what could be its most significant policy shift
in a generation on this deeply contentious issue
New points based system will prioritize skilled workers
with salary thresholds raised significantly from previous levels
Student visa regulations are also being tightened
with restrictions on bringing family members during studies
Universities have warned this could reduce international student applications
threatening a major source of revenue for higher education
The farming sector says it cannot survive without seasonal migrant labour
Fruit and vegetable growers report crops rotting in fields
due to insufficient workers available for harvest
Social care providers echo similar concerns about staffing levels
Many care homes rely on workers from overseas to fill critical positions
The government insists its approach will bring net migration down
while still allowing the brightest and best to come to Britain
Whether these policies will achieve their stated aims
remains one of the biggest questions in British politics today
Border Force officials report being overwhelmed by the scale of arrivals
Processing centres are operating well beyond designed capacity
The human cost of these policy decisions continues to mount
